title: 112_s647
content:
The Act is titled the "Montana Mineral Conveyance Act" and includes findings. Congress finds that the Secretary of the Interior has conveyed mineral rights in large coal tracts near the Northern Cheyenne Indian Reservation to the State of Montana. The development of these tracts and other energy resources in the surrounding areas generates significant public revenues for the State, aiding in addressing the impacts of development on the Northern Cheyenne tribal community. The Northern Cheyenne Tribe does not benefit from the public revenues generated by surrounding energy development, leading to economic hardships and lack of revenue sources to address development impacts. In 2002, the Tribe sued the Secretary over proposed conveyances of Federal coal tracts to the State. The Northern Cheyenne Tribe lacks revenue sources to address development impacts and sued the Secretary in 2002 over proposed conveyances of Federal coal tracts to the State. The Northern Cheyenne Tribe sued the Secretary in 2002 over proposed conveyances of Federal coal tracts to the State. The Tribe later withdrew the suit with prejudice, expecting legislation to be introduced to address the impacts of coal development near the Reservation. The Tribe retains claims against the United States for not acquiring mineral rights when the Reservation was expanded in 1900. The Tribe retains claims against the United States for not acquiring mineral rights when the Reservation was expanded in 1900. If mineral rights conveyances are carried out under this Act, the Tribe will waive all legal claims against the United States related to the loss of mineral rights on Reservation land. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "Cheyenne tracts" refers to a 5,000-acre land located in the eastern portion of the State within the boundaries of the Reservation, as depicted on a map dated April 7, 2010. The term "Federal tracts" refers to unleased land located in the State, including specific sections in T. 2 S., R. 44 E., T. 3 S., R. 44 E., and T. 3 S., R. 44 E. The term "Federal tracts" refers to unleased land located in the State, outside the Reservation, consisting of approximately 5,000 acres. These tracts are depicted on a map dated March 18, 2011, and include specific sections in T. 3 S., R. 44 E., and T. 3 S., R. 45 E. The term "Great Northern Properties" refers to land located in specific sections in T. 3 S., R. 44 E., T. 3 S., R. 45 E., T. 4 S., R. 44 E., T. 6 N., R. 27 E., and T. 6 N., R. 27 E. The term "Great Northern Properties" refers to specific sections in T. 6 N., R. 27 E., including sec. 10, sec. 14, and sec. 22. It includes the Great Northern Properties Limited Partnership and any successor owning coal or iron under the Cheyenne tracts. Other definitions include the Northern Cheyenne Reservation, the Secretary of the Interior, the State of Montana, and the Northern Cheyenne Tribe. SEC. 4. MINERAL RIGHTS CONVEYANCES. Great Northern Properties will convey mineral interests to the Tribe, and in return, the Secretary will convey coal rights to Great Northern Properties. The conveyed mineral interests will be immune from state taxation. SEC. 5. TERMS AND CONDITIONS OF MINERAL CONVEYANCES. The Tribe will waive legal claims in exchange for mineral conveyances. The Tribe and Great Northern Properties must agree on a revenue-sharing formula for coal production. Mineral conveyances must be completed within 90 days after the agreement is reached. After meeting conditions, mineral conveyances must be completed within 90 days. If invalidated by court, conveyances can be rescinded by the Secretary or Great Northern Properties. If a mineral conveyance under section 4(a) is invalidated by a Federal district court and not overturned on appeal, the Secretary or Great Northern Properties can rescind the conveyance. This rescission would also revoke the Tribe's waiver under subsection (a). SEC. 6. ELIGIBILITY FOR OTHER FEDERAL BENEFITS.

No benefits provided to the Tribe under this Act shall affect their eligibility for any Federal services, benefits, or programs due to their status as a federally recognized Indian tribe or as individual members of the Tribe.

SEC. 7. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS.

Appropriations necessary to carry out this Act are authorized.
